query: What did Barry Hughes think about the law and its application?

query: What was the potential barrier to implementing this proposed law?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked if there was a potential barrier to implementing this proposed law. Barry Hughes answered that there was not. The criminal law provided a general framework within which to operate, which most people tend to understand. There was a shortage of registered intermediaries in Wales, and the Ministry of Justice had taken action to deal with that, and they had had a number of people who were now in a position to act as intermediaries. So, the fact that they might not have many prosecutions was not a reason not to say that they shouldn't signify that certain behaviour was or was not acceptable.

query: What did Barry Hughes think about the number of cases that reached double figures?
summary: Barry Hughes thought that it was extremely unlikely that they would even have referrals that reached double figures on these cases. They were likely to be very limited. When the CPS was asked to conduct a survey across all of England and Wales—this was the review in 2007—it spanned just over a two-year period, and there were 12 cases that were brought up at that stage. Now, I have to say, I don't think that's entirely reliable, but it is indicative. They had a Freedom of Information Act request at one stage, which threw up something like three cases in a year. So, if you think about that as being all of English and Wales, and they make up about 5 per cent of the volume of criminal prosecutions nationally—you can see why the numbers are likely be small, for the reasons we've explored about getting past the evidential stage into the public interest.

query: What is the potential barrier to implementing this proposed law?

query: What did Industrial Designer think about the casing of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer explained that there were three different casing possibilities. The uncurved or flat case was the most common remote control form. The curved one was curved in two dimensions and was a bit like a wave shape. The double-curved one was more advanced and could be used with rubber buttons and scroll-wheels.

query: Summarize the discussion about the various buttons and scroll-wheels on the remote control.
summary: The group discussed the various buttons on the remote control, including push buttons, scroll-wheels, LCD displays, and double scroll-buttons, as well as the voice recognition item and sample sensor and sample speaker. The group agreed to use a scroll-wheel with the infrared issue because it would be different from the traditional devices on the market and attract the young customers. However, the group did not agree to use the voice function because they thought it was dull to talk to a device if you had to point to another device. Also, they did not want to use LCD displays because it was not flashy and new and there were no flat areas where they could incorporate these things.

query: What did Industrial Designer discuss about the solar power and the scroll-wheels when discussing the functional design of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer explained that the traditional solar power was just a piece of material on the remote control which transferred light energy into electricity. The push-buttons and the scroll-wheels could also be integrated with buttons. In the indicators, there were LCD displays, which showed the channel selector and the amount of volume. The scroll-bar was new and attractive to the young customers, so it might attract young customers. The group agreed to make four push buttons in a form of a round, and a mute button on the side.

query: What did the group decide about the chip when discussing the finance part of the project?
summary: The group decided that if they had enough space in their finance, they could integrate the chip into the remote control, but they could keep the regular version, which was a bit more costly. If they wanted to use the scroll-wheels, the speaker, the speak recognition, the rubber, the fancy colours, the LCD display and the scroll wheels, they would need the regular one, but if they didn't want to use any of these more advanced functions, they can keep with the simple chip, which is a bit cheaper.

query: What did Dafydd Evans say about employers' understanding of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: According to Dafydd Evans, most employers in Wales are small or microbusinesses. And while there are lots of small engaged employers who have taken an interest and do understand, the vast majority are more focused on getting on with the day-to-day running of the business. And that means it's quite a challenge to understand what is the Welsh baccalaureate, what does it offer, and whether that's developing the skills that employers require is very questionable. Also, it's a rigorous, some would say demanding, qualification, which is putting a lot of pressure on in terms of bureaucracy, in terms for staff and the student getting all the information together at the end of the year. And, so, the understanding is quite limited amongst the employers they work with.

query: What did Kay Martin think about the employers' views on the baccalaureate?
summary: Kay Martin thought that the employers wanted to make sure that their employees got the right qualification. They were having enough headache getting around the differences with apprenticeships and the levy between England and Wales, and changes to qualifications. They wanted their employees to get their main qualification. So, if you're an engineer, they want to get the engineering qualifications and they wanted them to be literate, numerate, and they want them to have digital skills. And that isn't captured necessarily in the Welsh baccalaureate.

query: What did Ed Evans propose to do to improve employers' understanding of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Dafydd Evans suggested that the baccalaureate should be reviewed so that employability skills and entrepreneurial skills have more of a role within the qualification. Ed Evans agreed that there were opportunities to join up employers and schools and education facilities a lot more than they do at the moment. And the only way they would get employer buy-in was if they felt ownership of what was being done.

query: What did Janet Finch-Saunders AM think of the problems with the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Janet Finch-Saunders AM thought that there were a number of priorities. One of the problems was that they had a lot of children coming in to the colleges, and they needed to resit their GCSEs—in maths, English and Welsh. But that ate into the time that the teachers had to teach young people. Another problem was that the Welsh baccalaureate was a combination of qualifications; it's not just one qualification—it's a combination. And, obviously, when you were trying to achieve outcomes, and all got funded on the outcomes, that became the priority, and sometimes then they lost the focus on the skills, which were ultimately what were supposed to be part of the development for employability.

query: What did the Duke of Edinburgh think about the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: The Welsh baccalaureate is a combination of qualifications; it's not just one qualification—it's a combination. But when learners are focused, if they are a learner, on developing or achieving certain qualifications to make up the Welsh bac, they lose the focus on the skills, which are ultimately what were supposed to be part of the development for employability. And the Duke of Edinburgh thought that this was something that we need to think about.

query: What did Dafydd Evans think of the problems with the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Dafydd Evans thought that one of the problems was that there were a number of priorities. There were children coming in to the colleges, and they needed to resit their GCSEs—in maths, English and Welsh. But that ate into the time that they had to teach young people. So, the priorities, I think, across the sector were GCSE resits rather than doing the Welsh baccalaureate at present.

query: What did Kay Martin think about universities' attitude towards the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Kay Martin thought that universities in the main did not believe the value of the Welsh baccalaureate, especially the experience they had with some of their learners to go to Russell Group universities. About 20 per cent of the learners went to Russell group universities, and there was no doubt that 50 percent of those, they did not value the baccalaurate. But if they did offer an option with Welsh bac, they said it was on top of three A2-level grades. So, to a certain extent, it was less of a problem. In terms of Bangor and Glyndŵr University, they had a long track record of getting learners into top universities. Because of the nature of their catchment area, there was a greater percentage of their students staying in Welsh universities and they were always trying to push their learners beyond.

query: Would their admissions tutors prefer four A-levels?
summary: Kay Martin: Cardiff University—yes. A great number of our learners get into Cardiff using the Welsh baccalaureate, but would their admissions tutors prefer four A-levels? Absolutely. So, they do, especially now it's graded at level 3. Then they do accept it.

query: What did Dafydd Evans think about the situation in Bangor and Glyndŵr University?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the situation in Bangor and Glyndŵr University. Dafydd Evans answered that there was no problem there. Because of the nature of their catchment area, there was a greater percentage of their students staying in Welsh universities, and, as Kay said, Welsh universities were much more willing to recognise the baccalaureate. So, to a certain extent, it was less of a problem. But, naturally, they did have students who were looking to go out to universities in England in the Russell Group, and they were having the same experience there where there were differences between the policy that that university extols and what actually happened on the ground when students had interviews in those universities.

query: What did Dafydd Evans think of introducing a specialist teacher-training qualification to deliver the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: According to Dafydd Evans, training is required regarding the Welsh baccalaureate, but where they are seeing it more successfully is where vocational lecturers have actually taken it on board. When they were bringing lecturers from outside, it was not working well. Now, a number of those staff have already got those skills and they're undertaking that. It's been an intensive staff development process. Now if that was rolled out across the board, it would make it easier for teachers in particular, but they are going to struggle to deliver some of these commercial and world-skilled, global areas because it's not their bag.

query: What did Dawn Bowden think about improving the status and perception of the Welsh baccalaureate?
summary: Dawn Bowden AM thought that introducing a specialist teacher-training qualification to deliver the Welsh baccalaureate would actually help in some way in improving its status and perception and so on. What do you think about that?

query: What did Dafydd Evans think of the Welsh baccalaureate contextualisation?
summary: Dafydd Evans thought that if the Welsh baccalaureate was going to be a success, it had to be contextualised, and for the vocational lecturers to do that, and they had invested heavily in training those vocational. It had been an intensive staff development process.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think of the curriculum when talking about the future of education?
summary: According to Kirsty Williams, there had been some changes to the curriculum in the past and there would be further changes in the coming years. There would be a change in the way that the curriculum was delivered, and the curriculum would be more flexible and more flexible in terms of how it dealt with different subjects. The curriculum would also have to adapt to meet the changing needs of the students.

query: What did Sian Gwenllian AM ask about the broad concepts that would expect to be delivered in each of the areas of learning and experience?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked about the broad concepts that would expect to be delivered in each of those areas of learning and experience. Kirsty Williams AM explained that they had the four purposes, and then there were the areas of Learning and Experience, and below those were broad concepts of what matters, what they believed matters, in that area of learning, and it was that that would now actually put into the legislation.

query: What did Claire Bennett think of the 'what matters' when talking about the articulation of the big ideas?
summary: Claire Bennett explained that the 'what matters' were the articulation of the big ideas. They were always intended to represent, as a whole, the learning that every learner should get. Therefore, it was not going to be on the face of the Bill—the mental health aspect, for example. But the provision would be there, and they would have the status of something that's not optional, basically, for a school.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think of WISERD when talking about potential unintended consequences?
summary: According to Kirsty Williams, Welsh Government are big supporters of WISERD and the work that they do, and, in fact, they need more research into Welsh education, not less. Therefore, they find their papers really helpful and help us to inform our work. Closing the attainment gap is a core element of the national mission for education in Wales and they would not proceed with anything that they thought could lead to an exacerbation of an achievement gap.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think of the curriculum in itself when talking about its enabling purposes?
summary: According to Kirsty, the curriculum in itself is neither going to necessarily on its own hugely enhance equity nor detract from equity, in the sense that the curriculum is what's taught in our schools. What will make the curriculum a success for all of our children, and I believe will have a bigger impact on children who are in danger of being left behind, are the four enabling purposes of the curriculum. The first one is strong leadership of our schools that ensures that there is no segregation, that has high expectation of all of the children. The second one is excellent teaching. The third one is assessment and accountability. The fourth one is the well-being of the child.

query: What lessons were being learned from the introduction of their curriculum?
summary: Kirsty Williams thought it was always useful to reflect on how other systems had undertaken curriculum reform in their nation and to learn from any issues that have arisen. Although their curriculum was not a copycat, as Kirsty Williams said, they had been able to learn the Scottish experience as part of some of their curriculum and assessment groups and some of the advice that they had had in terms of developing coherence. Assessment has been a crucial part of the process that they have been involved in.

query: How was the money that Kirsty Williams announced for supporting teachers for the preparation of the implementation of the curriculum?
summary: According to Kirsty, it was the largest investment in professional learning since the history of devolution. So, investing in the profession was absolutely crucial. Because, as I said earlier, the curriculum itself can be amazing, but if our teachers and our professionals were not equipped to deliver it, then all this change would be for nothing.

query: What was the national element to the professional development preparation?
summary: According to Kirsty, there was a national element to it, but they had given the money to individual schools and individual headteachers because they had no way of knowing how each individual practitioner was ready or how much additional support they were going to need. So, they were looking at developing potentially a stronger set of support, again on a national basis, for those who were newly qualified, beginning their teaching career, because they didn't think they had done that on a consistently good level across the country. They were also working with the regions to revisit and improve their coaching and mentoring schemes that they had across the system. There would be an ongoing programme of preparation development and personal development, as well as anything else.

query: What did the innovation schools do during the first term of work?
summary: The innovation schools have led to a very specific piece of work as they do the final refinement, and their main role is working with us on these final refinements to the content but also to the assessment issues and accountability issues. During the first term of work, they asked them to really look at the curriculum as a whole—so, take the whole curriculum guidance and then think, 'How would I apply that in the school? Does it make sense?, Can we work with it? What are the issues? What arise for us for assessment?', and each of the schools produced a report setting out their reflections on, 'If I were putting this into practice'. So, it's slightly different to the feedback they've had from other people, which has been more, 'Maybe you should emphasise this or change that wording' and kind of quite practical, and really about how you would realise this curriculum in a school.

query: How was awareness and understanding of human rights, including children's rights, being embedded in the new curriculum?
summary: Janet Finch-Saunders AM asked Kirsty Williams AM to respond to the concerns expressed in the children's commissioner's quarterly report of July 2019 that consultation materials were not released until mid June, allowing just over a month for young people to engage. And they said it was disappointing that a plan was not in place at the start of the consultation period. And Kirsty answered that they had been working with the children commissioner's office to map the rights of the child across each area of learning and experience.

query: What did Sian Gwenllian say about the Welsh dimension in the new curriculum?
summary: The Learned Society of Wales had said that there needed to be a directory of resources to implement that Welsh dimension. The Welsh Government had agreed to publish such a resource.

query: Why was the Welsh Government opting out of the creative thinking tests with regard to PISA 2020?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM asked why the Welsh Government was opting out of the creative thinking tests with regard to PISA 2020. Kirsty Williams AM explained that the key factor for making that decision was in 2021 they would be expecting schools to be right in the middle of their preparation for the introduction of the new curriculum. Therefore, they were asking enough of people at the moment and this would be an unnecessary addition to cope with. Moreover, they had a separate programme of work that was ongoing to look at resources that were needed to support the curriculum. And this proposal by the Learned Society would be considered as part of that work.

query: What did the group discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: Marketing suggested making the remote control the same style as the television, so that it would be easy to be seen from the outside, and the infrared would be from a good quality. User Interface suggested making it clear so that kids and the elderly could use it, but Project Manager thought it was too expensive to put a touchscreen on it. Industrial Designer thought it probably would be universal, but User Interface thought it had to have a lot of functions, so it should be smaller than the things they see now. Project Manager agreed and suggested that they could make it smaller and more trendy by using mobile phones that could fold open.

query: What did the team discuss about the finance of the project?
summary: Project Manager informed the team that they had to sell the remote control for 25 Euros to make a profit of 50 million Euros. The production cost were about half the price of selling price, so the profit would be easy. However, the team was not sure about making a universal remote control because they sell it apart from the television.

query: What did the project manager think of using a touchscreen on the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer suggested that they could design a small touch screen on the remote control to keep it easy and small. However, the project manager thought that it would be too expensive to put a touchscreen on it.

query: What did Project Manager and Industrial Designer discuss about recharging the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer suggested putting the remote control in a recharger or a home station. Project Manager thought that the home station was a good idea because lots of people would lose their remote control and don't know where it was, so it would be better to put it always at the same place. However, the cost of the rechargers was not clear, so they had to look at the market and decide whether to sell it separately or buy it separately.

query: What did the group discuss about the basic layout of the remote control?
summary: The group agreed that the on off button must be on top and the TV channels one two three four as a block, the volume obviously on top, and the basic options on top so that the user can see. They also agreed to have the basic things on the same place, like on the basic buttons on the remote control, and buttons that users don't use often as well as the strength and for everything together.

query: What did the group discuss about the appearance of the remote control?
summary: Marketing suggested that the remote control should lay good in the hand and the buttons should be on usable places, the on off button must be on top and the TV channels one two three four as a block, and the volume obviously on top so that users can see. User Interface suggested that they could have the basic things on the same place, like on the off button on top, TV channels on one side and volume on the other side, so that the user can see it. However, Industrial Designer pointed out that it would be hard to make it special if they did not have a lot of testing to see if it really worked.

query: What did PhD F think about summarizing meetings?
summary: PhD F thought that it would be too hard to have fifty different kinds of meetings without a good grasp on what does it mean to summarize. He would like to have different meetings by the same group but hopefully with different summaries.

query: What did Postdoc E think about native speakers?
summary: Postdoc E thought that it would be useful to advertise to linguistics grad students to get more native speakers because there would be so many people who had proficiency enough in English that their fluency and writing skills could be useful for purposes. Postdoc E also pointed out that for some time now, going back through BeRP, they have had speakers that they have worked with who had non-native accents and the accent was not the problem. The problem was more with the habits.

query: What did PhD F think about recording people?
summary: PhD F thought that the linguistics department could set up a room in another building to record people. They would need to find someone on campus who was interested in this.

query: What did PhD F think about meeting data?
summary: PhD F thought that the team should have a fair amount of recorded with a small number of types of meetings, but they could also have another part that was just one or two meetings of each of a range of them and that was OK too.

query: What did Grad B think about disk resources?
summary: Grad B informed the team that they were slowly getting to the point where they had enough room to record meetings. However, the archiving program did take a long time. Grad B was in the midst of doing a bunch of archiving, and it took eleven hours to do the clone.

query: What did Grad B think about disk space?
summary: Grad B informed the team that they were getting a new disk rack and four thirty-six gigabyte disks. The SUN rack took more disks than the Andatico one, so they were looking into other vendors.

query: Summarize the team's discussion about the product evaluation.
summary: Marketing first presented the results of the last meeting, which showed that seventy five percent of the users found most remote controls ugly and seventy-five percent of users thought it was hard to make a beautiful remote control for children and elderly. The team agreed that they had to make the product special and make it stand out by having good usability. They also agreed to make it for old people.

query: Why did Marketing think that remote controls were bad for television?
summary: Marketing thought that it would take too much time to learn how to use a new remote control. Therefore, a remote control for only television was out of the question. Besides, younger people were more interested in new features and older people wanted to keep the old things the old way.

query: What did the group discuss about the usability of the remote control?
summary: Marketing suggested that the remote control should be made for television because the elderly people needed to use it and the company should put the fashion in electronics so that it would be unique and stand out. However, User Interface pointed out that there were already many controls out that support lot of stuff, so they had to make sure that the product could stand out by just looks of it.

query: What did User Interface think about the technical functions design of the remote control?
summary: User Interface thought that the remote control should stand out by having a different shape and be unique with the design so that it would stand out from other remote controls in the market. Besides, it should be easy to use so that the elderly people would not have to remember the number of buttons. The group agreed to keep the basic functions like volume, channels, the basic on-off button and the menu button simple and standard. There should also be a button to go to the channel you've been before and a back button, like a web browser back button.

query: Summarize the discussion about the evaluation of the remote control.
summary: The team agreed that the fancy look-and-feel of the remote control was good, but it was not as fast as a usual remote control because it lacked fancy features such as the flashing lights and the colours. Also, the speech function and the colour were new, but the second layer was not easy to use. However, the team thought that they had done a lot of detail in the design of the front and the back, so they could change the colours and the front could be different colours. The team also agreed that they could make the backlight different colours and different fronts for a remote control, so the team could make a different style of remote control. Besides, there was a power indicator, a slide, a backlight, a speaker and a recharger.

query: What did the group discuss about the learnable part of the remote control?
summary: Marketing thought the scroll wheel was handy, but the first time the user got the remote control in his hands, it was not to use it. User Interface thought speech, scroll wheel and slide were easy to use. However, the second parts, like speech, etcetera, would be harder to learn.

query: Why did Industrial Designer reject the idea of adding a speaker to the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer proposed to add a power indicator to the remote control so that users could see how far the battery was charged up. However, this idea was rejected by the rest of the team because it would not be usable under the logo. Also, the speaker was very small and the cost of the product was 12.3 Euros.

query: Summarize the discussion about the product evaluation.
summary: The team agreed that the smart board was okay, but they got the wrong information at the wrong time and the digital pen was too slow to work. Also, they had a hard time drawing on the blackboard because the walls were thick and it was hard to make accurate drawings. The team agreed to make a remote control with a favourite for their text and a touch screen for all their stuff.

query: What did User Interface think of the third meeting of the project?
summary: User Interface thought that the team got the wrong information at the wrong time. For example, the prices of the remote control could be twenty Euros or something now. Therefore, they could have had discussion much quicker.

query: Summarize the team's evaluation of the product.
summary: Marketing presented the evaluation criteria based on the user requirements and trends found in the marketing reports and marketing strategy of the company. The criteria included fancy look and feel, technological innovation, easy to use, incorporation of current fashion trends and easy to locate. The team agreed that the spongy texture and the fruit and vegetable colour of the remote control were the two main ones. The design should minimise RSI and be easy to find. The group also agreed that a beeper function would be a good addition to the product.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about the colour of the remote control when talking about the use of materials for the prototype?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the base colour of the remote control would be white or light blue and the plastic would be a light blue, but the changeable faces would allow users to get any one of a number of colours that could be customised. The spongy feel would be in the rubber case, so it would not be hard plastic.

query: What did Project Manager think of the question does the design minimise repetitive strain injury?
summary: Marketing thought that the team had not come up with anything that could feasibly reduce the risk of repetitive strain injury. Project Manager suggested that the type of button that they were going to use in the bottom half, the material, minimised RSI because it was meant to be. However, Project Manager also pointed out that with the amount of stuff they were putting on the remote control, it was not necessary to move around trying to hit accurately the buttons in between.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the prototype of the remote control.
summary: Industrial Designer first introduced the prototype of the remote control, which was a regular chip on print and double-curved. Then, the group discussed the price of the product, and finally, they reached a consensus that the product would be priced at 12.5 Euros. However, they decided to change the battery to a standard one instead of a kinetic one, because they believed that customers would not be willing to pay more for a battery for a remote control.

query: What did the team discuss about the battery?
summary: User Interface suggested that they could change the battery to a standard one. However, Industrial Designer argued that it would not make a huge difference because customers never said anything about the battery.

query: What did the team decide to do when discussing the voice recognition feature of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the voice recognition was unnecessary because it would not make a difference to the price of the remote control, but Project Manager argued that customers were willing to pay more for better products. Project Manager also pointed out that voice recognition would set the product apart from the crowd because it was something completely different associated with the company. Therefore, the team decided to offer voice recognition initially to business class customers.

query: What did the group discuss about the additional learning needs sector?
summary: According to Sharon Davies, it was difficult to plan ahead, and from year to year and also within the term. Moreover, there was variation from week to week sometimes in the level of provision that a school had to provide for trying to retain those pupils in mainstream schools. Therefore, the additional learning needs sector was adversely affected, but certainly there was pressure, in particular with the new Act coming in, and that was going to place more pressure on the system. Also, in fairness to PRUs, they had been trying to work on the fact that, if children move out of school, the funding followed them. And what was really highlighted was the importance of the school being inclusive, and for that child, regardless of whether they had an additional learning need or not, to have proper opportunity to progress.

query: What did WLGA's David Hopkins think of the difficulties that can arise between the money that is kept back by local authorities and the funding that goes directly to schools?
summary: According to David Hopkins, the delegation levels are already very high in most authority areas, and they've got agreements in place with the Government to make sure that more money, or as much money as possible, is devolved to schools. The factors that really affect exclusions are the very narrow measure at the end of key stage 4 attainment, which has put pressure on some schools, certainly, and headteachers have felt that—sometimes excluded, or otherwise put into another school as a consequence, which is regrettable, but that's what's happened. So, there are financial pressures there, but I don't think the levels of delegation have any impact on that.

query: What did the WLGA think about the difficulties that could arise between the money that was kept back by local authorities and the funding that went directly to schools?
summary: Sian Gwenllian AM thought that it was important to understand how the money that was kept back by local authorities and the funding that went directly to schools would affect the kind of provision that was happening from authority to authority. The WLGA thought that there was a need to have a clear understanding of what was happening in terms of how that money was spent.

query: How effective are Torfaen at reintegrating young people into mainstream education?
summary: According to Nick, at least one authority is looking at how they can best retain all pupils in the school setting, but it's early days yet for looking at that. They have had a big investment of time, and there will be money and through band B, they're building a brand-new PRU provision in Swansea, which will be open in January 2021. There's an integration through a part-time timetable back into school, and they continue to support them during that process. But then, when they're back in school, that support doesn't stop—that support continues, and then there's a managed reduction in that support. It comes back to that team-around-the-family approach, to ensure what is needed for that learner to go back to school, what can the school provide.

query: What did Nick Williams say about reintegrating young people into mainstream education?
summary: According to Nick Williams, the more challenging learners are the ones who are coming to the end of their statutory education, your key stage 4. It is far, far more difficult when they're 15, 16 to get them back into mainstream. So, then you're looking more at how you transit, then, into further education and colleges and so on.

query: What did Kirsty Williams think of the effectiveness of Torfaen at reintegrating young people into the mainstream education system?
summary: According to Kirsty Williams, Torfaen had done a very good job of integrating young people into the mainstream education system, and they had had a really good relationship with the Welsh Government in terms of how they had worked with them.

query: Summarize the discussion about EOTAS provision.
summary: According to Nick Williams, Swansea was struggling sometimes for additional provision because they were restricted on how much access they got into the home. However, they did not want to make it too difficult, so that they haven't got any providers coming forward either. Therefore, it was a little bit of a balancing act. Moreover, they needed to perhaps think about how the staff in that sort of additional provision would quality assure it, and what sort of training and support they had.

query: What did Janet Finch-Saunders think about home tuition?
summary: Janet Finch-Saunders thought that the difficulty with home tuition was that as a local authority, they were restricted on how much access they got into the home. Therefore, local authorities should take a greater role in quality assuring individual tuition.

query: How did they quality assure other forms of provision?
summary: According to Nick Williams, they were restricted in that respect. They did not use agency staff, for instance, to go in and provide a few hours of provision, or to go to the local library. So, for whatever reason their needs at the moment couldn't be met in a school or in approved provision, then the staff who did provide some education, or if it was for medical reasons, they worked for them in the local authority.

query: What did Dr Ian Johnson say about the mental health issues of EOTAS learners?
summary: According to Dr Ian Johnson, there was a lack of awareness of the link between inequality and mental health issues among EOTAS learners, and a gap between being in mainstream education and entering any form of EOTA provision due to capacity or otherwise. There was a need to focus on a distressed young person and how they could respond to that, and it was also important to have a whole-school approach to ensure that the learners had access to a broad and balanced curriculum, and that there were learning opportunities that were appropriate for them.

query: What is the current situation of EOTAS?
summary: According to Sharon Davies, it is getting better, as Nick mentioned. It is an improving picture, but it is limited. There really isn't the capacity for them to access professional training. They need a group of people in the future to fill those gaps. There are networks now, there are conferences. But they could be doing more there, and it's probably, the group I chair, a discussion they need to have.

query: What did the meeting discuss about transport for EOTAS learners?
summary: Janet Finch-Saunders AM asked whether there were any issues relating to transport for EOTAS learners, particularly in more rural parts or areas of Wales. Nick Williams answered that they had got provision in the north and south of the county, but the distances that those learners were having to travel were huge. The WLGA had not got any comment on the transport issue.

query: Summarize the group discussion about the functions and target audience of the new remote control.
summary: User Interface proposed two kinds of remote controls, a multi-function one with many possibilities and an ease-of-use one with fewer possibilities. Project Manager preferred the easy-to-use remote control with fewer buttons, but Industrial Designer preferred the combination of the two. The group agreed to skip the teletext function and to have only one function, the programme to programme button, which could be pushed in four directions. query: What did Project Manager think of the changes in their plans when discussing the details of the remote control?
summary: Project Manager informed the team that the remote control would not use teletext, it would not be a control for everything and they had to incorporate the image of the company into it somehow. They had decided on a flip design and a different shape from what's normal. They were also going to look into rechargeable batteries and an alarm for getting it lost.

query: What did Marketing think about market trends?
summary: Marketing informed the team that the most important aspect for remote controls was fancy look and feel, followed by technologically innovative and easy to use. Marketing also mentioned that fruit and vegetable themes were going to be the theme for clothes, shoes and furniture this year. There also seemed to be a trend towards a spongy feel to materials in contrast to last year.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about the circuit board design of the remote?
summary: Industrial Designer pointed out that most current remotes use a silicone PBC board which has contacts that are really close together and when the user presses down on the rubber button, it will connect the circuit and each switch is connected to two different legs on the chip and so sends a different message to the chip, which gets translated by the chip into a code and then it's fired out of this L_E_D in the sequence of on and off bursts.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about the battery options when discussing the functional design of the remote?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the standard double A and triple A batteries were a bit too bulky at the moment, dynamo charging was a bit silly to be honest because people wouldn't use it for very long and it was basically like wind-up radio. Solar charging was not very resistant to dropping because most people had the light on in the room anyway so they could get the signal when they got TV. Besides, the battery life of the solar battery was not too long.

query: What did Industrial Designer think of the case material when discussing the disadvantages and advantages of titanium and plastic when talking about case material?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the main problems with the case material were that titanium was expensive just to process and it would be expensive to buy a new case for it. Also, there were quite a few design restrictions that they had got on the shape of the case, so if they went for titanium they could only do a standard box shape, whereas if they came to plastic they could be a little more elaborate and do sort of curved shapes.

query: What did Industrial Designer think of the LCD screen when discussing the interface designs with the buttons?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that the LCD screen could fit inside the shell, but the problem with it was that it was flat and so they couldn't do lots of curve things with it. Then Industrial Designer suggested that they could have rubber buttons which were made of anti-RSI material and they could arrange the buttons on the screen in a sort of set thing.

query: What did Industrial Designer think of Marketing's idea of using a small pointer thing when discussing the functions of the remote control?
summary: Marketing proposed that when the remote control was opened up, people could use their fingers to press the button, or they could pull out a small pointer thing when they wanted to. However, Industrial Designer thought that the pointer could get lost easily and would spoil the touch-pad very fast compared to a button if people kept punching with an pointer. So, Marketing proposed that they could use a palm pop thing instead.

query: What did Industrial Designer think of the mirror effect when discussing the flip-top concept?
summary: Marketing suggested that when the flip-top shell was opened, it would be like a compact mirror that responded to the turn of the body. However, Industrial Designer was not sure if they could get any mirror effect on it because if they just put the full charge through an LCD display it would completely blank it out.

query: What did the team discuss about battery design?
summary: Industrial Designer suggested that the team could choose from two types of batteries. The standard double A and triple A would be the cheapest, but the dynamo would take more space because it would be so expensive to buy a new case for it. The team also discussed whether they could have a touch screen.

query: What did the team discuss about the design of the remote control?
summary: User Interface pointed out that there were too many cluttered buttons, repetitive buttons, and no particular remote control was standard. Also, there was a lack of variety in the standard remote control, so the team decided to keep the standard buttons and make it trendy and technologically innovative. The team also agreed to have a G-U-I interface in the middle of the flip-top and to incorporate voice recognition for the finding it.

query: What did the group discuss about designing a remote control in black and white?
summary: Industrial Designer thought it would be quite fun to design a remote control in black and white. Project Manager thought the only pitfall would be how much it would cost if that meant they had to cut down somewhere else. The LCD was not cheap, so they could start with the black-and-white one and could upgrade later.

query: Summarize the discussion about Industrial Designer's presentation.
summary: Industrial Designer presented some initial ideas about the implementation of things, and the technical possibilities and impossibilities. He also reminded the team of some new technical possibilities available and which might be interesting to implement in the product. The main points of Industrial Designer's presentation were focus on the inter operability, one remote control should control one or more pieces of equipment and the way of communicating with these equipments.

query: What did Industrial Designer think of the interoperability of the remote control when discussing the technical function?
summary: User Interface suggested that the remote control should work on different TVs or even different devices. Industrial Designer disagreed and pointed out that they were not developing this product for a specific vendor, but for a broad public. Therefore, the technical function should be pure and just changing the TV's state.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about the interoperabi interoperability of the new remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought a modern remote control should control a diverse subset of equipment, for instance, DVD players, cell phones, video and audio equipment. Therefore, there should be some interoperabi interoperability between them. Industrial Designer also proposed some implementations for that, but there might be some impossibilities.

query: What did the group discuss about the remote's technical input?
summary: Industrial Designer thought infrared was not really hot technical stuff anymore, so they should think about the things like Bluetooth. Project Manager thought Bluetooth might be problem because Bluetooth was use a lot. However, all the TVs were equipped with infrared, so it was cost-effective. User Interface suggested that they could equip infrared and Bluetooth together in one remote.

query: What did Industrial Designer think about the infrared remote?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that infrared was not really hot technical stuff anymore, so they should think about the things like Bluetooth. But all the TVs were equipped with infrared, so it was cost-effective. So User Interface suggested that they could equip infrared and Bluetooth together in one remote.

query: What did Project Manager think of the Bluetooth connection when discussing the functional design of the remote control?
summary: Industrial Designer thought that Bluetooth might be a problem because it was use a lot. Project Manager was not sure about this because cell phones had integrated Bluetooth also and it seemed to work quite okay. So Project Manager suggested that only light the buttons that were applicable at that moment.
